functions.cellular_process: HDAC6 directly deacetylates the outer mitochondrial membrane protein Miro1, a key adaptor for mitochondrial transport, thereby inhibiting the movement of mitochondria along axons.
functions.effect_description: In the presence of central nervous system (CNS) axon growth inhibitors like myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG) or chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPGs), a signaling cascade involving RhoA and ROCK is activated. This leads to HDAC6-mediated deacetylation of Miro1 at lysine 105 (K105), which reduces the motility of mitochondria. This arrest of mitochondrial transport in axons contributes to the inhibition of axon growth and regeneration.
biological_consequence: CNS axon growth inhibitors (MAG, CSPGs) → RhoA/ROCK signaling pathway activation → Intracellular Ca2+ increase → HDAC6 deacetylates Miro1 at lysine 105 → Reduced mitochondrial transport along axonal microtubules → Axon growth cone collapse and inhibition of regeneration.
specific_effects: Deacetylation of Miro1 at K105 by HDAC6 is a critical step that blocks mitochondrial transport.
Inhibition of HDAC6 with Tubastatin A increases the acetylation of Miro1 in axons and restores mitochondrial transport.
An acetylation-mimicking mutant of Miro1 (K105Q) is resistant to the inhibitory effects of CSPGs on mitochondrial transport and axon growth.

evidence.paper_title: Deacetylation of Miro1 by HDAC6 blocks mitochondrial transport and mediates axon growth inhibition
evidence.relevant_quote: Exposing neurons to MAG and CSPGs decreases acetylation of Miro1 on Lysine 105 (K105) and decreases axonal mitochondrial transport. HDAC6 inhibition increases acetylated Miro1 in axons, and acetyl-mimetic Miro1 K105Q prevents CSPG-dependent decreases in mitochondrial transport and axon growth. MAG- and CSPG-dependent deacetylation of Miro1 requires RhoA/ROCK activation and downstream intracellular Ca2+ increase... These data point to HDAC6-dependent deacetylation of Miro1 as a mediator of axon growth inhibition through decreased mitochondrial transport.

evidence.paper_title: HDAC6 and Miro1: Another interaction causing trouble in neurons
evidence.relevant_quote: Deacetylation of Miro1 decreased mitochondrial transport in axons and attenuated the axonal growth cone. Changing the lysine 105 acetylation site in Miro1 into an acetylation-mimetic, thus preventing any negative effect of HDAC6, was sufficient to counteract the decrease in mitochondrial transport and growth cone size induced by CSPG. Moreover, HDAC6 and Miro1 interact as both proteins could be coimmunoprecipitated.

support_summary: HDAC6 interacts with and deacetylates the mitochondrial Rho GTPase 1 (Miro1), a key regulator of mitochondrial transport, thereby inhibiting axon growth.
mechanism: HDAC6 directly deacetylates the outer mitochondrial membrane protein Miro1, a key adaptor for mitochondrial transport, thereby inhibiting the movement of mitochondria along axons.
effect: In the presence of central nervous system (CNS) axon growth inhibitors like myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG) or chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPGs), a signaling cascade involving RhoA and ROCK is activated. This leads to HDAC6-mediated deacetylation of Miro1 at lysine 105 (K105), which reduces the motility of mitochondria. This arrest of mitochondrial transport in axons contributes to the inhibition of axon growth and regeneration.
summary: HDAC6 inhibits Miro1 to modulate mitochondrial axonal transport, ultimately affecting axon growth cone collapse and inhibition of regeneration.

evidence.paper_title: Deacetylation of Miro1 by HDAC6 blocks mitochondrial transport and mediates axon growth inhibition
evidence.relevant_quote: Exposing neurons to MAG and CSPGs decreases acetylation of Miro1 on Lysine 105 (K105) and decreases axonal mitochondrial transport. HDAC6 inhibition increases acetylated Miro1 in axons, and acetyl-mimetic Miro1 K105Q prevents CSPG-dependent decreases in mitochondrial transport and axon growth. MAG- and CSPG-dependent deacetylation of Miro1 requires RhoA/ROCK activation and downstream intracellular Ca2+ increase... These data point to HDAC6-dependent deacetylation of Miro1 as a mediator of axon growth inhibition through decreased mitochondrial transport.

Changing the lysine 105 acetylation site in Miro1 into an acetylation-mimetic, thus preventing any negative effect of HDAC6, was sufficient to counteract the decrease in mitochondrial transport and growth cone size induced by CSPG.
